bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 166, Number 71 (Tuesday, April 14, 2020)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. JACKSON LEE:H.R. 6503.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article I, Section 8, Clauses 1, 3, 17, and 18of the United States Constitution.[Page H1889]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Appropriations.

item.name: Department of Housing and Urban Development
Emergency medical services and trauma care
Housing for the elderly and disabled

summary.text:
Pandemic and Public Health Emergency Support for the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities Act

This bill provides funds for the Department of Housing and Urban Development to provide additional housing support services to elderly individuals and individuals with disabilities in federally owned or subsidized housing in response to the COVID-19 (i.e., coronavirus disease 2019) public health emergency.

bill.title: Pandemic and Public Health Emergency Support for the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities Act

item.title: Pandemic and Public Health Emergency Support for the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities Act

To provide housing support services to the elderly and individuals with disabilities living in Federal Government housing or federally subsidized housing during the Pandemic or Declared Public Health Emergency.
Pandemic and Public Health Emergency Support for the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Appropriations.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
